definition: Given a passage, construct a question on the basis of the information present in the passage. Construct the question in such a way that (i) it is unambiguous, (ii) it is answerable from the passage, (iii) its answer is unique (iv) it answer uses text phrases from the passage. Avoid creating questions that (i) can't be answered correctly without actually understanding the passage and (ii) uses the same words or phrases given in the passage.
context:
The Dyson device, which combines noise-cancelling headphones with a mouthpiece that blows filtered air, initially caught my attention. As someone who suffers from noise-induced migraines and chronic nasal congestion due to environmental pollutants, the idea of having a personal zone of quiet and clean air seemed appealing. However, upon closer inspection and a brief trial, I found the headphones heavy and the mask impractical for public use. Moreover, the notion of isolating myself in a filtered bubble while living among others felt discordant. Ultimately, I decided against purchasing the device, but it made me contemplate the allure of retreating into a personal bubble versus engaging with the world.

In my case, although I refrained from embracing the air bubble, I acknowledge that I've created a bubble of my own by living in a private condominium and owning a car. I justify these choices by considering the hard work I put into improving my social status. To assuage any guilt, I make efforts to engage with the community and support charitable causes. However, the temptation to gradually slip into a life of privilege is ever-present.

Take transportation choices, for example. Initially, one may rely on public transport but occasionally opt for a taxi or private-hire car. As circumstances change, such as receiving a transport allowance or having limited time, the convenience of private-hire services becomes more enticing. Eventually, the calculation is made, and owning a car seems more advantageous, especially when coordinating transportation for a partner, children, or elderly parents. Climbing the career ladder may bring additional perks like a dedicated parking space or even a company car and driver. Before realizing it, one becomes accustomed to being chauffeured and grows frustrated when faced with the inconvenience of parking independently.

Human nature exhibits a dual tendency to seek both connection and separation from others. Historically, communities formed to facilitate collective tasks, with shared values of reciprocity and fairness. As societies became more complex, hierarchies emerged, naturally attributing higher status and rewards to those deemed more powerful or deserving. Paradoxically, one of the rewards for merit is the ability to distance oneself from the masses. This tendency to create social disparities is intrinsic to capitalist systems, evident in the stratification of travel classes, tiered hospital beds, and the allocation of corner offices.

Today, not only elite groups but also the upper-middle class can afford to shield themselves from poverty, hunger, noise, and pollution. Although such inclinations are instinctive, they must be resisted. This requires not only individual effort but also societal consensus to ensure that average lives are not so disheartening that everyone seeks to escape them.

The most effective approach lies in elevating the quality of public services that cater to the masses. Singapore serves as an excellent example, with its high standards of public housing, education, and healthcare. When public services are of good quality, fewer individuals feel compelled to seek private alternatives. This positive feedback loop encourages even the elites to utilize public services and compels policymakers to maintain high standards.

However, even when amenities are well-designed, the antisocial behaviors of some users can drive others away. For instance, public housing may be aesthetically pleasing, but inconsiderate behaviors like noise pollution and littering can mar the living environment. Similarly, schools may offer a quality education, but disruptive student behavior can hinder learning and push parents toward expensive private schools. Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Ultimately, each person must strike a balance between participating in the vibrant tapestry of the world and creating personal bubbles. Personally, I appreciate living in a city like Singapore but find the constant noise overwhelming. If people collectively reduced the noise they generate—speaking softly, playing music at lower volumes, and minimizing the use of noisy machinery—Singapore would become a quieter and more pleasant place to live. As for now, I have decided against acquiring my own purified air and noise-free Dyson Zone, but who knows what the future holds.
output: What is the author's opinion on the Dyson device and the idea of creating a personal bubble?

The author is initially interested in the Dyson device but ultimately decides against purchasing it, citing the heavy weight of the headphones and the impracticality of the mask for public use. The author also notes that the idea of isolating oneself in a filtered bubble while living among others feels discordant. Therefore, it can be inferred that the author has a negative opinion of the Dyson device and the idea of creating a personal bubble.

Take transportation choices, for example. Initially, one may rely on public transport but occasionally opt for a taxi or private-hire car. As circumstances change, such as receiving a transport allowance or having limited time, the convenience of private-hire services becomes more enticing. Eventually, the calculation is made, and owning a car seems more advantageous, especially when coordinating transportation for a partner, children, or elderly parents. Climbing the career ladder may bring additional perks like a dedicated parking space or even a company car and driver. Before realizing it, one becomes accustomed to being chauffeured and grows frustrated when faced with the inconvenience of parking independently.

Human nature exhibits a dual tendency to seek both connection and separation from others. Historically, communities formed to facilitate collective tasks, with shared values of reciprocity and fairness. As societies became more complex, hierarchies emerged, naturally attributing higher status and rewards to those deemed more powerful or deserving. Paradoxically, one of the rewards for merit is the ability to distance oneself from the masses. This tendency to create social disparities is intrinsic to capitalist systems, evident in the stratification of travel classes, tiered hospital beds, and the allocation of corner offices.

Today, not only elite groups but also the upper-middle class can afford to shield themselves from poverty, hunger, noise, and pollution. Although such inclinations are instinctive, they must be resisted. This requires not only individual effort but also societal consensus to ensure that average lives are not so disheartening that everyone seeks to escape them.

The most effective approach lies in elevating the quality of public services that cater to the masses. Singapore serves as an excellent example, with its high standards of public housing, education, and healthcare. When public services are of good quality, fewer individuals feel compelled to seek private alternatives. This positive feedback loop encourages even the elites to utilize public services and compels policymakers to maintain high standards.

However, even when amenities are well-designed, the antisocial behaviors of some users can drive others away. For instance, public housing may be aesthetically pleasing, but inconsiderate behaviors like noise pollution and littering can mar the living environment. Similarly, schools may offer a quality education, but disruptive student behavior can hinder learning and push parents toward expensive private schools. Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Ultimately, each person must strike a balance between participating in the vibrant tapestry of the world and creating personal bubbles. Personally, I appreciate living in a city like Singapore but find the constant noise overwhelming. If people collectively reduced the noise they generate—speaking softly, playing music at lower volumes, and minimizing the use of noisy machinery—Singapore would become a quieter and more pleasant place to live. As for now, I have decided against acquiring my own purified air and noise-free Dyson Zone, but who knows what the future holds.
output: What is the main idea of the passage?

The main idea of the passage is to discuss the concept of personal bubbles and the tendency for people to retreat into them, as well as the impact this can have on society. The passage also touches on the idea of seeking isolation during the COVID-19 pandemic and the importance of balancing the desire for personal space with the need to engage with others.

Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Ultimately, each person must strike a balance between participating in the vibrant tapestry of the world and creating personal bubbles. As for now, I have decided against acquiring my own purified air and noise-free Dyson Zone, but who knows what the future holds.

As societies became more complex, hierarchies emerged, naturally attributing higher status and rewards to those deemed more powerful or deserving. Paradoxically, one of the rewards for merit is the ability to distance oneself from the masses. This tendency to create social disparities is intrinsic to capitalist systems, evident in the stratification of travel classes, tiered hospital beds, and the allocation of corner offices.

Today, not only elite groups but also the upper-middle class can afford to shield themselves from poverty, hunger, noise, and pollution. Although such inclinations are instinctive, they must be resisted. This requires not only individual effort but also societal consensus to ensure that average lives are not so disheartening that everyone seeks to escape them.

The most effective approach lies in elevating the quality of public services that cater to the masses. Singapore serves as an excellent example, with its high standards of public housing, education, and healthcare. When public services are of good quality, fewer individuals feel compelled to seek private alternatives. This positive feedback loop encourages even the elites to utilize public services and compels policymakers to maintain high standards.

However, even when amenities are well-designed, the antisocial behaviors of some users can drive others away. For instance, public housing may be aesthetically pleasing, but inconsiderate behaviors like noise pollution and littering can mar the living environment. Similarly, schools may offer a quality education, but disruptive student behavior can hinder learning and push parents toward expensive private schools. Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Moreover, the notion of isolating myself in a filtered bubble while living among others felt discordant. Ultimately, I decided against purchasing the device, but it made me contemplate the allure of retreating into a personal bubble versus engaging with the world.

In my case, although I refrained from embracing the air bubble, I acknowledge that I've created a bubble of my own by living in a private condominium and owning a car. I justify these choices by considering the hard work I put into improving my social status. To assuage any guilt, I make efforts to engage with the community and support charitable causes. However, the temptation to gradually slip into a life of privilege is ever-present.

Take transportation choices, for example. Initially, one may rely on public transport but occasionally opt for a taxi or private-hire car. As circumstances change, such as receiving a transport allowance or having limited time, the convenience of private-hire services becomes more enticing. Eventually, the calculation is made, and owning a car seems more advantageous, especially when coordinating transportation for a partner, children, or elderly parents. Climbing the career ladder may bring additional perks like a dedicated parking space or even a company car and driver. Before realizing it, one becomes accustomed to being chauffeured and grows frustrated when faced with the inconvenience of parking independently.

Human nature exhibits a dual tendency to seek both connection and separation from others. Historically, communities formed to facilitate collective tasks, with shared values of reciprocity and fairness. As societies became more complex, hierarchies emerged, naturally attributing higher status and rewards to those deemed more powerful or deserving. Paradoxically, one of the rewards for merit is the ability to distance oneself from the masses. This tendency to create social disparities is intrinsic to capitalist systems, evident in the stratification of travel classes, tiered hospital beds, and the allocation of corner offices.

Today, not only elite groups but also the upper-middle class can afford to shield themselves from poverty, hunger, noise, and pollution. Although such inclinations are instinctive, they must be resisted. This requires not only individual effort but also societal consensus to ensure that average lives are not so disheartening that everyone seeks to escape them.

The most effective approach lies in elevating the quality of public services that cater to the masses. Singapore serves as an excellent example, with its high standards of public housing, education, and healthcare. When public services are of good quality, fewer individuals feel compelled to seek private alternatives. This positive feedback loop encourages even the elites to utilize public services and compels policymakers to maintain high standards.

However, even when amenities are well-designed, the antisocial behaviors of some users can drive others away. For instance, public housing may be aesthetically pleasing, but inconsiderate behaviors like noise pollution and littering can mar the living environment. Similarly, schools may offer a quality education, but disruptive student behavior can hinder learning and push parents toward expensive private schools. Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Ultimately, each person must strike a balance between participating in the vibrant tapestry of the world and creating personal bubbles. Personally, I appreciate living in a city like Singapore but find the constant noise overwhelming. If people collectively reduced the noise they generate—speaking softly, playing music at lower volumes, and minimizing the use of noisy machinery—Singapore would become a quieter and more pleasant place to live. As for now, I have decided against acquiring my own purified air and noise-free Dyson Zone, but who knows what the future holds.

The author ultimately decides not to purchase the device because it feels discordant to isolate oneself in a filtered bubble while living among others.

context:
The Dyson device, which combines noise-cancelling headphones with a mouthpiece that blows filtered air, initially caught my attention. As someone who suffers from noise-induced migraines and chronic nasal congestion due to environmental pollutants, the idea of having a personal zone of quiet and clean air seemed appealing. However, upon closer inspection and a brief trial, I found the headphones heavy and the mask impractical for public use. Moreover, the notion of isolating myself in a filtered bubble while living among others felt discordant. Ultimately, I decided against purchasing the device, but it made me contemplate the allure of retreating into a personal bubble versus engaging with the world.

In my case, although I refrained from embracing the air bubble, I acknowledge that I've created a bubble of my own by living in a private condominium and owning a car. I justify these choices by considering the hard work I put into improving my social status. To assuage any guilt, I make efforts to engage with the community and support charitable causes. However, the temptation to gradually slip into a life of privilege is ever-present.

Take transportation choices, for example. Initially, one may rely on public transport but occasionally opt for a taxi or private-hire car. As circumstances change, such as receiving a transport allowance or having limited time, the convenience of private-hire services becomes more enticing. Eventually, the calculation is made, and owning a car seems more advantageous, especially when coordinating transportation for a partner, children, or elderly parents. Climbing the career ladder may bring additional perks like a dedicated parking space or even a company car and driver. Before realizing it, one becomes accustomed to being chauffeured and grows frustrated when faced with the inconvenience of parking independently.

Human nature exhibits a dual tendency to seek both connection and separation from others. Historically, communities formed to facilitate collective tasks, with shared values of reciprocity and fairness. As societies became more complex, hierarchies emerged, naturally attributing higher status and rewards to those deemed more powerful or deserving. Paradoxically, one of the rewards for merit is the ability to distance oneself from the masses. This tendency to create social disparities is intrinsic to capitalist systems, evident in the stratification of travel classes, tiered hospital beds, and the allocation of corner offices.

Today, not only elite groups but also the upper-middle class can afford to shield themselves from poverty, hunger, noise, and pollution. Although such inclinations are instinctive, they must be resisted. This requires not only individual effort but also societal consensus to ensure that average lives are not so disheartening that everyone seeks to escape them.

The most effective approach lies in elevating the quality of public services that cater to the masses. Singapore serves as an excellent example, with its high standards of public housing, education, and healthcare. When public services are of good quality, fewer individuals feel compelled to seek private alternatives. This positive feedback loop encourages even the elites to utilize public services and compels policymakers to maintain high standards.

However, even when amenities are well-designed, the antisocial behaviors of some users can drive others away. For instance, public housing may be aesthetically pleasing, but inconsiderate behaviors like noise pollution and littering can mar the living environment. Similarly, schools may offer a quality education, but disruptive student behavior can hinder learning and push parents toward expensive private schools. Such antisocial actions in shared public spaces can fuel the temptation to retreat into personal bubbles.

As social creatures, humans are driven to socialize, as evident during the Covid-19 pandemic. When individuals desire isolation, it is crucial to discern whether they are avoiding public spaces themselves or the people frequenting them.

Ultimately, each person must strike a balance between participating in the vibrant tapestry of the world and creating personal bubbles. Personally, I appreciate living in a city like Singapore but find the constant noise overwhelming. If people collectively reduced the noise they generate—speaking softly, playing music at lower volumes, and minimizing the use of noisy machinery—Singapore would become a quieter and more pleasant place to live. As for now, I have decided against acquiring my own purified air and noise-free Dyson Zone, but who knows what the future holds.
